title: SUPPORTS PLEASE READ THIS !!!
body:
im about to give you the most important lesson you may ever learn and a lesson that will make every adc cry please duo after game senpai.(third time writing this fml)

rule number 1: push for level 2!!!!!! if you arent actively autoing creeps at level 1 i already dislike you seriously either stop their adc from hitting creeps or you have to make sure your autoing them yourself now this doesnt mean take the cs but get that shit low as fast as possible, it takes 1 wave + 3 melee creeps to hit 2 make sure you are in position to engage if you are about to hit 2 this can make or break bot lane.

rule number 2: stay parallel with your adc keep a nice straight line with you and your adc this means that you can both engage and disengage together this parallel line should only break during engages or disengages during lane phase if you arent doing either stay parallel please !!

rule number 3: ward at the right times their adc is gone back great ward, their support is gone ward or maybe kill the adc then ward ;)

rule number 4: ward in the right place lane is pushed = river and their tri under tower means the back lane brush and the close river brush

rule number 5: if you have a decent roam support go mid through the lane after your first b works like a charm

this is all i have right now may add if you found usefull

Attacking the minions basically. You don't want to kill them usually because your ADC needs the gold, but you want to help get their health low so your ADC can kill them faster and you gain exp faster. In lane often there will be a fight once either you or the enemy hits level 2, and whoever has level 2 will have the advantage.

since the topic of this thread is about support
one question that's been in my head for a while now, if you could answer that's would be great
coz i play support alot, and i have encounter a problem many times

for example, during a lane fight at early stage
after my ADC takes down one enemy and the other one trys to run with minimal hp
my adc is clearly outside atking range, and i know i can kill the enemy
for a few time i took the kill and got called KSer, "your job is to support me not KS me noob!"
and for a few time where i decided no to take the kill, and was asked why i let enemy escape
so i am confused...

should i as a support, 
ignore the fact that my ADC might or might not have the ability to take down this running enemy
(with his/her ult or other means)
and make the kill myself when i feel necessary just to be sure?
as a support, do i have the rights to make decision like such?

If the ADC doesn't have good chances of getting it, take it. In fact really, unless it's a kill that's guaranteed and easy to leave for them, don't worry about trying to leave it, and if you get it you get it. Your ADC should know their limits, and while you shouldn't be stealing kills from them, if they are out of range or in a bad position, securing that kill is your best option. 

Unfortunately though, you will face ADCs who don't know their limits and who will think they can get a kill when they cant, or who don't realise their support isn't in a position to leave a kill for them. Of course this is only really a bad thing if they then abuse you for it, you have to learn somehow. Assists are still worth quite a bit, and if you are in a position to make such a decision, it usually means the ADC is out of position for the kill, and you are better off taking it. Better an assist for them than nothing at all.

Every support makes a mistake and steals an easy kill to give every now and again, but most ADCs in my experience will be pretty ok with it so long as you apologise for that sort of thing. Another good way to stave off their frustration when you do choose to take a kill, is to say something like "Sorry but I wasn't sure you'd be able to get it". Usually any who are a little frustrated will be ok with the fact that you acknowledge the action and what it meant, and any who still take offence are generally mute worthy anyway.

Regarding rule 1 how does this fit with freezing the lane?

It's only until you hit level two (or three if you have a significant spike there, say, Vel'koz support, a personal favourite to play ^^) You shouldn't have any need to freeze the lane at this time because the enemy will be pushing for those early levels as well (at least their ADC will be).

For rule 2 though I would say there are a few exceptions. If you are playing Braum and have a dominant early then you may want to be a bit in front and off to one side to hit the q poke or set up for the stun. If you are playing Soraka then you likely want to play a bit behind your adc and sustain off pots in the early rather than your q if they are dominant or if you are really squishy. 

It kinda comes down to playstyle here, but having a very good understanding of that parallel line is important, regardless of where you choose to sit relative to it. I tend to play aggressive supports like Nami so I'm usually sitting a bit in front of my ADC, but I've mained support for a long time and have a pretty good understanding of how strong I am vs how strong they are and where I can or can't get out if I have to. As far as general advice goes, he makes good points.
I try not to push lanes. I pull them instead because it makes my lane safer and exposes my opponent to friendly ganks. Personally I would be a bit pissed if my supp was pushing lane.

I had an ADC rage at me and feed because I didnt go back when she wanted me to (even though I was full health and had my support item with first upgrade and a spare health potion and had no valid reason to go back etc etc)

But if you have nothing to do in lane, and the wave is pushed, then you can't safely get experience and won't gain anything by staying. It's a good opportunity to either roam mid or to go b and buy a pink ward or some such. Doesn't excuse that kind of behaviour from a player, but there is a certain logic there. 

If you have nothing to gain by going b, and nothing to gain from staying, try going elsewhere. Otherwise go b and make the most of it and come back with your ADC.
